Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2011 10:14AM BeckyOD wrote: I've been dealing with liver mets for nearly 6 years. Taxotere/carboplatin put me in NED after 6 months but only for 4 months. I've been on gemzar, Xeloda, navelbine, taxol, and Abraxane. We revisited the Taxotere/carb in there again. It had been a miracle combo for me but then it stopped working. Nothing else has been more helpful than slowing the progression and containing the lesions to the liver and spine. I'm surprised your onc didn't do a full round on navelbine. Doxil has helped a friend of mine a lot. So hopefully it will for you as well. Yes, you are in quite a battle. Big hug.
Posts.Title: Calling All Liver Mets-Need Input dragonfly stitchyphish

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2010 10:35AM BeckyOD wrote: Boy Jennifer, you said it. Between the bloating, wigs, and addled brain I don't even remember where my eyebrows need to be painted on. One friend I hadn't seen in 4 years came by and looked startled when she saw me...and I thought I looked pretty good that day! No one I love will tell me how weird I look and always say I look great. Nice of them but great, compared to what? A cow, a monkey? Your post hit a nerve for me I guess. Vanity is a grey area, one I cling to for some delusional sanity. Easier to worry about my looks than the state of my health. Neither worrying seems to improve either though.

Posts.Title: Zappity Do Da - My WBR konakat konakat

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2011 10:07AM BeckyOD wrote: Time is such a funny thing. We are told this terrible thing one day and we are sure every day or month might just be our last. Then we hit an anniversary of that heart stopping news and think: wow, can I have some more please. My DH found this lovely poem I thought I'd share. It's by an Irish poet named Derek Mahon called Dream Days. I hope it doesn't offend anyone. I persoanlly fill my days as best I can, and I think they're quite full, but I just hit my 6th anniv and can't believe how the years flew by even if the days were rich. When you stop to consider The days spent dreaming of a future And say then, that was my life. For the days are long-- From the first milk van To the last shout in the night, An eternity. But the weeks go by Like birds; and the years, the years Fly past anti-clockwise Like clock hands in a bar mirror.

Posts.Content: BeckyOD wrote: I've been on Abraxane for 7 months with stable scans. Since the last scan though my tumor markers have been soaring. So I did the only thing I could think of: take a treatment off and go to NY with my DH. As my reward, I guess, my onc decided to add carboplatin to treatment yesterday. Within an hour I was very chilled and violently throwing up. Then my temperature spiked to close to 102. They sent over a nurse with meds so I'm much better today in that "I've-just-had-chemo way". Has anyone had this combo and, if so, did you have a bad reaction? One other woman at my center also had a bad reaction a couple of weeks ago. The onc is talking about changing the carboplatin to cisplatin. I'm thinking not. Dx 2/21/2005, Stage IV, 0/18 nodes, mets, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2011 12:15PM BeckyOD wrote: No windy, the feeling doesn't fade with time. It is eased with information. Ask everything you can think of from every source, and be insistent about understanding what it all means to you specifically. I'm so sorry that you got this one two punch from the start. Your choices will differ a little. You are allowed to ask for an anti anxiety or anti depression until you feel you are absorbing the mounds of news you have to decipher. This site can be a great resource and comfort for you. Don't be shy. For now, I'm sending many hugs and much support.

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2011 05:13AM BeckyOD wrote: Geez, hezzy, that's a lot of steroids without break or relief. Sounds necessary but harsh. See if the onc will allow you some Lunesta or AmbienCR for the sleep you desperately need. I understand about liking the warmth on your feet after the neuropathy issue but do be concerned that Xeloda will go to the extreme with drying and cracking on both hands and feet. Keep moisturizer with you and use it all the time. I used udderly smooth in tubes I could carry in my purse (bought at an online drugstore). I took your meaning of balance to be more of the troubles of when to take what, how to remember. Those are a lot of different pills for one to remember to take and without sleep I'd be terribly confused. Is there someone that could be responsible for sorting out and be your manager of pill taking? If not, maybe a pharmacist could give a suggestion with pill boxes or even they could set one up for you. hugs....
Posts.Title: schedule to meds hezzy BeckyOD

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2011 10:20PM BeckyOD wrote: Some oncs can be overly aggressive with something like this but that's not always the wise way to play it. Unless there's been a change in the nodule I would tend to not panic. I know how scary it must be for you to think it may get out of control but it's been stable for over 3 scans. Probably will be for a long time.
Posts.Title: PET scan results, now in my lungs?? undecided8 undecided8

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2011 10:43PM BeckyOD wrote: I was on Xeloda for a little over a year. Most of the time was stable, not really improvement but no progression. The last few months the TMs rose some and the dose was increased, don't remember amounts any more. But the TMs never came back down so we moved on to another drug. I feel I may be able to go back to it someday since it's been years but the change was a good choice at the time. Don't think that was what you were hoping to hear but it's all I've got.

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2011 01:35PM BeckyOD wrote: There has been a lot of good advice here and I echo a lot of it. What bothers me most from your post is the boyfriend thing? Toxic is the right word that lowrider said. You are not his mother but he is a selfish child. I'd rather live on my own forever than to be bullied into taking care of a person so demeaning. Cancer IS a big deal and real and cannot be yelled away. If you don't take of yourself you won't make NED which is what we're all aiming for, for a long long time. I say pull the bandaid off and get out of there. BTW, a third floor walk up? You'll be unhappy with that on chemo. Trust me. I have a two story home. The one flight at this point is tough enough. Get the help YOU need. You deserve it.

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2011 06:10AM BeckyOD wrote: I was told radiation to the spine was the treatment of choice. I had 2 lesions radiated 3 years ago and they are gone, still. We added Zometa to help build the bones making them stronger so new lesions would less likely cause a fracture. I have developed a couple very small lesions in a different area and may have to address them sometime. If you're in pain I'd think you'll definitely benefit.

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2011 02:31PM BeckyOD wrote: Fantastic news from the MRI! Headaches come from so many sources. If you've taken taxotere, which screws with the sinuses, and you had that cold, maybe you are experiencing sinus headaches as you feel. I hope the headaches are just that simple.
Posts.Title: Good Results of Brain MRI SusanR mcbird

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2010 01:29PM BeckyOD wrote: I agree with the folks here: you need to ask the doc about a sleep aid and to up that dosage of pain meds. I use lunesta or ativan but it doesn't always help. Sometimes steroids can defeat any drug that aids sleep, at least for me. Staying in bed when the insomnia hits does me more harm. So I take to the couch and listen to books on tape - that way I can keep my eyes closed and pull off the earbuds if I actually start to fall asleep. I wish you a good night's sleep.Â
Posts.Title: TIRED! TIRED! FLIPPING NEEDHELP JustJudi cmhartley

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2010 02:50PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 06:03AM by BeckyOD Jenny, you may be projecting or misinterpreting your doctors' reactions. I know I do at times when I'm feeling particularly vulnerable and haven't had any good news in a long time, nothing to bolster me up. But my onc has nothing to bolster him up either. He sees my weakening state and he has no direction to send me. I see him hurting almost as much as me when he can't help me. That being said, I must say that when I come in for an appointment feeling pretty good and am personally feeling optimistic the appt goes very different, more upbeat and I can get a lot of answers and info that point in a positive direction. I'm not sure it's fear you may be getting from your doctor or helplessness. Some procedures and treatments can really cause us more harm than you and I could truly understand without a medical degree. Trust that this is hard for your medical team too. But hugs and support to you. It's all really crappy....

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2011 06:10AM BeckyOD wrote: So good of you to be helping your wife like this. She is very scared needless to say. She will be getting blood tests every month now for the rest of her life. Most of us live scan to scan, every three months. My markers have never given me proper info about the state of my cancer, so I try to ignore any talk of them. When I start feeling the anxiety before a new scan all the way to getting the results I take Ativan or Xanax. She must keep her stress levels down. And she needs to talk with someone. You've been chosen, be gentle. I had a question though. If she has changed to ER- why is she even on an anti estrogen? What benefit is she getting for all their side effects. May be part of my ignorance but I had to ask. Good luck to you and your wife. She'll come around to get help when she really needs the support. She'll know when that is. Trust her.

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2010 01:27PM BeckyOD wrote: It seems adjusting is what we're always doing in stage IV. There's no choice. When one avenue shuts off we find ourselves looking for new ways to occupy our minds, bodies, and souls with positive things while the doctors look for holding off progression. Focusing on what may be is emotionally harmful for me. So I focus on getting through the SEs and keeping myself doing the things that I can. BTW, permanent disability is not a bad thought if that can help you enough financially to let you focus on you. Exercise-endorphines, might help. Go for it.

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2010 03:26AM BeckyOD wrote: Yes, that is crappy news. So sorry to hear it. I was on Taxotere for 13 months starting with three weeks on 1 off. (Much easier SEs than once every 21 days.) After getting a handle on the SEs I tolerated it ok. It did kick the cancer's butt because after 3 months I went on an every other week at the 1/3rd dose. Finally I was able to go just once a month at the 1/3rd dose for 6 months until it finally stopped working. Although my hair began thinning after a couple of weeks it took nearly 6 months to lose all of my hair. Some people lose it in a couple of weeks. Have a great trip then kick ass.Â
Posts.Title: I've got crappy news as well Melanie36 Melanie36

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2010 11:27PM BeckyOD wrote: 5 1/2+ yrs in stage 4 for me. Constant chemo; 6 different ones, 3 revisited. A couple of rad txs. AIs stopped working after 2 years while in stage 3. It's been a real ride. Stubbornly I have refused to give in but the SEs sometimes concern me. Still doing pretty well. Actually am doing better than 6 months ago with the latest tx. Have taken on redecorating projects around the house and planning a trip to NYC with hubby in a couple of weeks. I wouldn't have traded these years for anything, even with the continuous adjustments needed for life and friends.

I've been through so many different combos of drugs I can't remember anymore what does what to eating probs. Eating smaller more frequent meals might help; it has me. Nice that your DH is so concerned but he may be masking his resentment since he's having the opposite prob and is jealous. Just a thought.Â

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2011 04:34AM BeckyOD wrote: I often marvel at the high costs being spent on all the treatments and tests, etc. You are certainly worth it, we all are. I look at it as we are all part of the big expensive experiment looking to cure a nasty beast. We get the benefit of more years with better QOL and maybe one day this experiment will yield the results everyone prays for. I do get upset when I hear someone can't have a treatment or procedure because of lack of proper (or no) insurance or money. I have no answers, just compassion.
Posts.Title: Do you ever think about the high cost of your treatment? MJLToday Alpal

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2010 05:00AM BeckyOD wrote: Hi Connie, I seem to be right where you are. I too have been on constant chemos (since Feb 05) without any real breaks. Every so often I ask for a couple weeks off to get a little stronger. Not sure it's that wise but I need the time off. It seems that once a drug "fails" the cancer has gotten a little worse. The new round of drugs is to try to get me back to where I was before the last one failed. Rarely has that worked out and I learn to accept my new "norm" for maintenance - but it's still being controlled and I'm thankful for that. After a recent progression I'll be starting my 6th different protocol on Tues. I asked my onc about using AIs again. He felt they hadn't been that useful to me but it couldn't hurt to ask your onc. What a road we're on. Becky
Posts.Title: chemo break chk8 konakat

Posts.Content: BeckyOD wrote: With Spring arriving for all of you who have had such a hard winter I feel the renewal and hope it brings all the way to So Cal. My last posting was so dark and needy I feel it's time to say goodbye to that with thanks to all of you for helping me through it. My edema is slowly but perceptibly going away. Other things are also clearing up. The progression is another thing but at the moment I have very short term plans that don't include thinking about it. Once I can walk without danger of falling and can bend my knees to drive by myself I am off to little local adventures around town, which can be numerous in L.A. So welcome Spring. We all need you. Posts.Title: A bit of upbeat BeckyOD chrissyb

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2010 12:46PM BeckyOD wrote: I've been on Abraxane for 7 months. My hair fell out slowly over the first 3 treatments and then this wispy thin hair started growing back. Never got longer than an 1 inch. It went that way for a couple of months but now it's almost all gone. A couple of others girls at the clinic have had the same thing in different variations but we're all wearing our wigs and wraps. Over the years I've invested in many head coverings and a few wigs just like I would have with jewelry and shoes...to match my clothes/mood. Certainly this is an annoying side effect but the easiest oneÂ for meÂ to handle.
Posts.Title: Hair -- Abraxane Experience?? Lynn1 jeanne46

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2011 04:01AM BeckyOD wrote: Yvonne, I very much understand what you're going thru. Been thru enough changes along the road to know that each new change in diagnosis changes everything. Not only do you have to come to terms with this personally but so do your friends. You have to accept things, they don't. Your real friends will come around when they've accepted their own fear of what's happening to you. Not everyone can do this so let them go. Time to join support groups and any new activities you can. At least you won’t be so lonely. Support comes from the oddest places sometimes, keep an open mind. In the meantime, hang tough. Loads of hugs.
Posts.Title: In need of a friend mossybaby chainsawz

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2011 12:44PM BeckyOD wrote: Today is a better day for me than the last several. Because of other complications I had to suspend the meds for the edema, which of course immediately got bad again. Now back on track I'm hopeful again. I'm working really hard to push past this but being stuck in bed or on a couch with legs raised does cut into doing much. Sigh.... It's raining here for the week but the temps are moderate. A good soaking for the flowers about to emerge. My favorite time of year. Thanks so much for keeping in touch. You guys lift my spirits a lot.
Posts.Title: A bit of upbeat BeckyOD chrissyb

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2010 09:08PM BeckyOD wrote: Hard to know what to say. BC mets is better than primary liver cancer, so they told me when I was in the same boat. Very sorry it came so quickly. Hope the treatment they outlined for you works quickly. hugs, Becky
Posts.Title: Liver Mets confirmed - now what? Ezscriiibe BeckyOD

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2011 01:04PM BeckyOD wrote: I'm all for it and, being somewhat legal in CA, I've had the opportunity to find clean strains that do target my ailment du jour. Pain and nausea seem for me to be the best help, often times insomnia. It does not help my anxieties over this disease. All that said, I find the fogginess of the chemo to be a deterrent to want to use pot very often and become more spaced. So I'm a partial fan. I never smoke it. I have a vaporizer and sometimes use the homeopathy style drops. Eating it is fine but there's always way too much sugar in the product and you can use too much very easily. I don't broadcast this use to anyone. It's a private decision. If the last 7 years had been a party and not constant chemos I'd be singing a different tune for its use -- but pot's benefits are definitely there for pain and chemo relief.
Posts.Title: Pot ~ weed ~ and other cures. :) lisa34lisa radiant

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2010 04:27AM BeckyOD wrote: Geez, so sorry to hear this. It's so unfair. Yes, it does get worse than this but THIS sucks big time too. Sending you both strength.
Posts.Title: Does it get any worse than this? cmhartley Padiddle

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2010 05:35PM BeckyOD wrote: Hi - I just posted a little rant...should have read other posts before I posted. Abraxane has worked well for me for 7 months with remarkably little SEs but then my markers went up, a lot, and right after a stable scan. In treatment yesterday Carboplatin was added to boost the Abraxane. I had a terrible reaction to the combo. You seem to have tolerated a couple treatments though. I wish you great success with getting good results or better. There's no reason to think otherwise. Hang in there.

Thanks for being part of our lives throughout. You both touched our hearts in a deep way with the courage, spirit, and loved you shared with us.
Posts.Title: Olga Simkin Z"L leprechaun Bestbird

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2011 06:35AM BeckyOD wrote: sfhusb, there has been many a conversation on these boards about "pep" talks from people who don't have stage iv. We kind of resent being told to be positive and to just plow ahead regardless of our pain and fears. Be understanding. She hurts, she's scared. She wants your strong shoulders and support. Guide her through her treatments and meds, and be an ear for her. Her journey is private. Be thankful if she includes you.
Posts.Title: How to Deal with Monthly Cancer Markers sfhusb susan_02143

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2011 02:30PM BeckyOD wrote: There is a fizzy powder called Calm at the health food store that you make into a warm tea. It's a magnesium supplement. One thing they tell you is to not overdo the quantity because it may loosen your bowels too much. I drink this in a small amount daily but take WAY too much when I'm constipated. As advertised it does loosen things up. And works pretty quickly for me, 8-12 hours. Sorry your suffering.
Posts.Title: constipation jleigh dreamwriter

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2011 12:25PM BeckyOD wrote: I see my onc whenever I go in, which depends on treatment schedules, scans, or just followup. My center is not compartmentalized. NPs are very knowledgeable but they can give some very wrong info. I need to have the rapport with my onc, who knows every detail of my case and has learned my tolerances and can answer my endless questions. He personally visited me in the hospital every day I was there. I don't think I could do this without a hands on onc.
Posts.Title: survey: how often do you see your oncologist? kristinpianista Lena

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2011 12:35PM BeckyOD wrote: What a perfect attitude. You should do all you want, with abandon. You go, girl! I always plan my next adventure when I return from the last leaving no seconds in between. This world is yours -take it.
Posts.Title: Screw It I'm Living!! FightnF8 WeeSee

Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2010 05:37PM BeckyOD wrote: Stephanie, so many things can cause a pain in your side. I've had liver mets for a long time but rarely feel anything and then only after having been given chemo. You have gone through so much personal loss. Losing your mother in itself is so devastating but add it to your dx just this past spring and -- well, that's a lot to bare. Be good to yourself. Rest as much as you can. And definitely enjoy your birthday!
